kernel-modules/qat17/files/Crypto-qat-Si.message:
The commit header should be preserved as much as possible from the original patch.  Here it looks like you authored the commit which is just wrong.  And you threw away most of the commit log.

Go to the original commit in Linus' tree, and use git format-patch on the commit.  Then "git am <patchfile>" to get it into your working tree.  If that git am fails, use the saved failing patch file to make the changes and then "git am --continue" to finish and preserve the git headers.  Or use any other approach you feel comfortable with to preserve the commit header.

Also, under the first line of the commit header which is also known as the short log, add the following line with a blank line before and after it:
[ commit 1b82feb6c5e1996513d0fb0bbb475417088b4954 upstream ]

Example:
-------------------------------------------------------
net-sysfs: Fix mem leak in netdev_register_kobject

[ commit 895a5e96dbd6386c8e78e5b78e067dcc67b7f0ab upstream ]

syzkaller report this:
BUG: memory leak
<rest of header not shown>
---------------------------------------------------------

Also make sure your Signed-off-by line is at the bottom of the header.

Then use git format-patch on it to produce the patch file.  Do not rename this generated patch file except for removing the number at the front of it.  Do not be lazy and directly edit patch files, always generate them with get format-patch.  I hope this helps.

guidelines/version-information-schema.js.message: BIKESHED: Weird mix of tabs and spaces here.

Couple things here.

- While I understand it's not always the case for JSON schema, unescaped '.' *can* match 'any character'.  (I tried it in python with jsonschema.Draft4Validator and that's the case.)  So the '.' should be '\\.'
- Assuming the above is fixed, this will still match some things I don't think you intended, including: 'v1.' (trailing period) and 'v1234' (four digits, no period).

Based on the other docs ([1], referred to by [2]), I got the impression that the full 'vX.Y' format was required here (just not in the URI).  If so, this might be better:

 "^v[0-9]{1,2}\\.[0-9]{1,2}$"

If the '.Y' part is indeed optional, suggest:

 "^v[0-9]{1,2}(\\.[0-9]{1,2})?$"

Also, are you sure you want to restrict the number of digits, at least in X?  I mean, sure, v123.45 may be a long way in the future, but similar thinking got us Y2K.  So I'm suggesting replacing (at least the first) '{1,2}' with '+'.

(NB: All of the above will still permit goofiness like 'v01.20'; not sure how hard you want to try to restrict those.)

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/459710/16/guidelines/microversion_specification.rst@19
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/459710/16/guidelines/discoverability.rst@148

Ditto '\\.'.

seems currently we are using ``latest`` in nova... should we consider to use lower case here?

Both the compute api and the placement api expect the string 'latest' in the 'OpenStack-API-Version' when requesting the latest version, and right now it is always lowercase. In the microversion spec it is also lowercase: http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/microversion_specification.html#client-interaction

This is because it's supposed to be a special token, not really a human string, so case matters.

However that may have been a bad decision.

In any case, the latest used in the header, and the latest being discussed here, though the same concept, are not exactly the same thing.

After I got to reviewing the next file, I got hopelessly confused. Is it a major or a micro version? It feels like you have a mix of both here.. E.g. you talk about discovering this "version" from an endpoint, and at the same time this section seem to be talking about microversions, as you talk about ranges..
This is all about major versions.

I slightly disagree here. I think it may be more useful to accept a list of versions rather than a range. A range means that the Application was tested and proved working against all versions in between. This is challenging in practice, and may be not too useful in the end. What we may end up in reality, is people testing only with min and max versions, assuming the versions in between will work. This is not a correct assumption from our standpoint, as we allow changes to be breaking. So, I'd prefer ['3.2', '3.10'] to mean "either 3.2 or 3.10", rather than "any version between 3.2 and 3.10".

Yah - what you said makes sense for microversions, but not for major versions because of the way they work. For this we're talking:

nit: from Python standpoint, we should accept tuples too, but I guess this document is too generic?
Yah - keystoneauth actually does accept tuples, but this is intended to be a description of semantics, not language impl details.
mmmm, versions are not in {service-catalog}, are they? I think you meant "they want to use whatever version is the default for the service"?

Versions are not in the service-catalog, but many services by historical convention put versioned endpoints in the catalog.

Omitting a version from an endpoint request means "please give me whichever endpoint I get by following what is in the catalog without trying to find a "newer" one if it exists.

A specific example is clouds that have put a v2 endpoint in the catalog for block-storage but run a cinder that has v3 support. the user not requesting a major api version will mean that version discovery will simply grab the endpoint in the catalog and consider that one "best" and will not go searching the service's version discovery document for a more current endpoint.

Ironic does not have to - this is ALL client-side consumption and how to match information returned from version discovery docs.

Maybe it's only me, but I don't find this option particularly practical. With the microversions taking over the world, it is essential to know the range of versions you work with. And as we don't encode microversions in the URLs (a bit mistake, if you ask me, but okay), it will be always required for fetch version information anyway, no?

No - there are plenty of clouds that do not have new enough services to have microversions, and there are plenty of services that don't have them yet. There are also users who do not need to do any microversion interaction for their application (I'm one of those at the moment) - and where the extra fetch to get the microversion range would be wasted.

This is implemented in keystoneauth but is mostly hidden from the user - it depends on which methods you call. For instance - session.get_endpoint() does not do a microversion fetch if it doens't otherwise need to to find the proper major version because it would discard the information before returning it. However, session.get_endpoint_data() (which will return metainfo about the endpoint including microversion info) will trigger an additional fetch to get microversion info even if the major version matches because it's necessary to provide the data.
Perhaps add some wording to explain that (and why) this isn't needed for services that implement microversions.
How should omitted be treated by the caller? Does it mean that the project does not support microversions? Can we assume that if max-version is None, min-version is also None?
Yes - omitted/None means the service doesn't have microversions.

api_version is always a major version.

One of the most important points that needs to be added somewhere is that finding major api version endpoint is about finding the endpoint to use from the catalog and version discovery. Microversions, on the other hand, are attributes of that major-versioned api endpoint - and should be applied on a request-by-request basis. So you need to find your endpoint for your connection, but then as you make calls you need to have the information to be able to decide which microversion, if any, you will request for that call.

With this approach, you can get the subnet ids from the Neutron port object(via fixed_ips) that is passed to the update_port() method; that represents the **current** state in neutron, and, in the same method you compare those IDs with the subnet ids we have in the OVN database which represent the **old** state, remember this is before we commit the change to the OVN DB.

I found it's because here mock_listdir is returning a file in the cache dir, when os.listdir(self.cache_dir) should actually raise FileNotFoundError if the cache dir doesn't exist.

Whereas with the way this is currently: (brace yourself for these shenanigans), we return a file for a non-existent dir listing from mock_listdir, so then we call os.path.isfile() with cache_dir/onefile, which calls os.stat(cache_dir/onefile) internally, then that raises FileNotFoundError because of the mock_stat.side_effect, then os.path.isfile() CATCHES OSError, of which FileNotFoundError is a subclass, ignores it, and returns False [1], and then we never make the os.stat() call that we wrote in get_disk_usage() and thus don't fail this test when the fix is removed. We only ever call os.stat() indirectly through os.path.isfile(), which is why the assert on L741 works. GUUHHHH

That all said ...

When I do mock_listdir.side_effect = FileNotFoundError I get the expected result of the test failing without the try-except fix and passing with it. And that behavior matches when I tried a local test, as calling os.listdir() on a non-existent dir will raise FileNotFoundError and then we never call os.path.isfile() nor os.stat().

[1] https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/fe75b62575bcfdf1c39be71c1e50257832a596db/Lib/genericpath.py#L25-L33

nova/virt/libvirt/imagecache.py.message: Why would we not put this in the property? Anything else that calls that will just need to do the same guard here. Surely properties are intended to provide stable results and not raise any exceptions whenever possible...

Now I think it was a mistake that we make this a public property, it should have been a private helper.

I don't want to make a assumption here deep in the image cache code how the imagebackend ensures that the directory exists later on. So I don't like the idea to fold the existence check into the same dev check. If the directory does not exists then the code cannot decide if it will be on the same or on different dev.

In the other hand when the caller ask the question what is the size of the cache, then if the dir does not exists then we know that it does not occupy any space so we can return 0.

If it doesn't exist now, and we return that it's currently using zero space (as in the latest version) then I don't see what the difference is.

You're making an assumption that st_dev != st_dev means they're separate, even though a complex filesystem could have a directory-based quota on the cache directory, etc, so I don't think that assuming st_dev will be the same on a directory we create in the future is unreasonable.

Plus, even if the assumption about how imagebackend creates this directory in the future changes, we run this periodically and will adjust our reporting if the _base directory moves at that point, right?

Note that, unless I'm missing something, the fact that _base doesn't exist yet necessarily means that they will be on the same filesystem, so it's fine to make the property return True in that case, as it will be created when we go to cache the first image, and will end up on the same filesystem.
This needs to be not-exists-or, instead of exists-and. If the thing *does not* exist, then it *will* be on the same device when we create it.

So we're using 'os.stat(path).st_blocks * 512' instead of e.g. 'os.path.getsize(path)'. Checked locally:

  $ dd if=/dev/zero of=sparse_file bs=1 count=0 seek=512M
  $ python
  >>> import os.path
  >>> os.path.getsize('sparse_file')
  536870912
  >>> os.stat('sparse_file').st_blocks * 512
  0

With that said, can't we just do?

  >>> os.stat('sparse_file').st_blocks
  0

Looks like it's the same thing from the docs [1]

  Number of 512-byte blocks allocated for file. This may be smaller
  than st_size/512 when the file has holes.

> We need to return bytes not number of blocks so st_blocks is not

Need to rephrase as one of the below.
"feature supports" (or)
"feature adds support for"
What exactly it means?Better to elaborate.

Rephrase it as below for better readability. May be if you can think of a better way to rephrase it that's fine.
"Ironic powers off iRMC server before starting the firmware upgrade. It powers on the server when ``File Transferred Successfully`` and reboots once the upgrade is completed."
This list has only one item, let's make it plain text. Also I have hard time understanding this sentence, maybe drop it completely?
"Here is an example of a firmware upgrade clean step::"
To make it closer to the existing iLO implementation, maybe s/type/mode/ ?
we have irmc and bios types -- I think we can use type in this situation.
For similar reasons, can we accept a list of images here? Otherwise it doesn't make much sense to call it "images"
yeah. It only support a image at the time.
bad indentation here, please check the rendered version (you can do it locally with `tox -edocs`).
why cover "file transferred successfully" with double ticks and make it camel-case?
This is msg from server which scciclient will be recieved during perform firmware upgrade --- Should keep this msg for make sence. thanks
"firmware" should go outside of double ticks. Also you seem to use lower case ``irmc`` and ``bios`` in your example.
"One one firmware update mode, either ``irmc`` or ``bios`` can be used at once."
s/type/mode/ for consistency with existing ilo and proposed idrac implementations. And let's maybe make it optional since you can derive it from the file extension?

Is it true that you can/need to update only one file per request? Does it make sense to be able to update iRMC and BIOS firmware in one request?

also s/_file// since you seem to accept not only local files, but also remote URLs

Yes. Fujitsu BM only support a drive upgrade at the time. It can support to process in one request, but it will take a long time to complete and have higher risk for our server if one of them to be failed firmwares. We will do one request in the next time when we can control them, such as boot time, stable time after upgrade. And we also allow operators upgrade to seperate in their bussiness.

About URL, currently Fujitsu cannot support to get firmware images from server directly --- We will implement this option later.
just a note that at the moment, according to the drivers requirements, we support pysnmp up to version 5.0.0 not included

I'm lining up things for Huaqiang. This reshape should only happen if the instance's CPUs have a "dedicated" policy since the "mixed" policy didn't exist when we added it. Put another way, any new instances created with a future mixed policy will obviously have been created on a host newer than Train, which means a host with properly reshaped inventory (PCPU + VCPU inventory, instead of just VCPU inventory). I explicitly check for dedicated to make sure we don't forget to *not* check for mixed in the future change.

ironic_python_agent/extensions/standby.p.message:
This is only:
1) DNS lookup
2) Cert lookup/validation
3) initial GET but NOT the actual transfer of content down from the server.

The timeout should generally cover this, but if we hang somewhere in places not covered (say dns lookup) this should cover it. The place where things _could_ go sideways in this case is in select in the socket handling on the tcp socket request, but that seems super remote and is not in the download where things can absolutely go sideways if the packet stream is interrupted.

It doesn't look like iter_content can yield empty chunks: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47978661/is-it-possible-for-requests-response-iter-content-to-return-empty-chunks and https://urllib3.readthedocs.io/en/latest/reference/index.html#urllib3.response.HTTPResponse.stream

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

ironic_python_agent/extensions/standby.p.message:
So, my head hurts.

It _looks_ like what occurs is urllib3 internally builds the buffer, tries to decode it, adds it to the data available to return and iterate through if possible. It looks like that can fall out with none when there is no new data to decode/assemble, which seems sporatic 

is_connection_dropped()->wait_for_read() -> wait_for_socket() -> epoll/poll/select (which is why eventlet+urllib3 does not get along, they both ultimately use the same toolset on sockets under the hood (and why trying to monkey patch makes things explode))
_last_chunk_time should be initialized here otherwise you may end up subtracting None

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Please expand on the sequence of events here. I'm not clear on why we have this race condition that requires the sleep.

As soon as the upgrade path & load signature have been successfully validated, sysinv-api fires off an async request to the conductor to do the actual import and returns a success response to the sysinv api proxy which copies the load files from the staging directory to dc-vault. Once the conductor has imported the load it updates the load status in the database from 'importing' to 'imported' and removes the files from staging directory to free up space on scratch.

This race condition was not observed in hardware lab where the feature was tested or in vbox running 20.06 load. However, it was observed in vbox running 20.01 load with load import dev patch. Perhaps the 20.01 conductor is not as busy as the 20.06 conductor. Hence load import by the conductor completes faster than the copying of large iso file to dc-vault by the sysinv api proxy. It could also be that this developer's vbox is slow and the file copying takes longer.

This wait does not affect the elapsed time of sysinv load import as the load status is updated before the wait. It just makes the conductor load import thread to linger a tad longer. Considering the frequency of load import, I wouldn't worry about this thread lingering for an extra 30s. Another option is to remove these files in the next load-delete request but they will take up 2.1G+ of scratch space for whatever number of months it takes till the next upgrade.
Sorry Tee - since this bug is now gated for stx.4.0 we'll need to put this back to Closes-Bug and open a new LP for the subsequent commit in stx.5.0.

- Update this code to first check if this is a DC system. If is, then wait for the .load_stored_in_vault file to appear (check every 10s) and if it doesn't appear after 30s, continue.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/common/inter.message: Are you OK with  [0124] being evaluated 01234,  whereas [124] ends up as 124.  ie: no leading zero, and no guarantee that this value is 4 digits

Hi Al, yes, I belive so.  The data in port['pdevice'] is generated from the lscpi cmd of the pciutils package.  This uses the pci.ids file to generate the class/vendor/description and should always be 4 digit hex value: https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man5/pci.ids.5.html .  For example, a device from my system with a leading 0 looks like: "GK208 HDMI/DP Audio Controller [0e0f]" with the actual sysfs entry looking like: 0x0e0f

doc/source/specs/stx-4.0/approved/suppor.message:
Hi Austin, 

I would suggest to change the scope of this spec. Although we are targeting small nodes in this approach, the same procedure can be true for any other non-starlingx node that an user may want to add into the k8s/starlingx cluster.

If we have a "custom-node" (or other name) personality and the needed containerized services, then it will be possible to add any worker node, with any OS (k8s complaint), to the starlingx cluster.

There are several use cases that can be enabled with this model and having a node with small resources is one of them. But also, there are different reasons on why an user don't want (or can't) install StarlingX in some nodes, like: 

  - Need specific kernel to support hardware or performance improvements.
  - Need a non-CentOS OS installed.
  - Even considering a hybrid k8s cluster (ARM workers for example) would more feasible.

So, this model can add a layer of flexibility to users and can help community adoption. The trade off is that this nodes won't have the full set of features as a StarlingX node, but giving the users this opportunity it could be helpful.

Hi, Erich:
   Thanks your advice and review. i will consider and change it.
e
sorry, should this be omitted ?
yes
Ok. will do it.
It would be helpful to describe use cases you are trying to address here. What use cases need the smaller footprint ?
OK. will do.
I agree with Brent. We should target smaller compute nodes (Core, Atom) as well.  Note that the node has to support VT, which not all Atom cores do.
What are the cpu requirements ?
This seems odd to me. I would think you are targeting small nodes more just reduced memory
don't have any special request for cpu/disk, as long as the system can run k8s/docker.
:). Yes , but usually small nodes is smaller memory. :) maybe I can change this spec to small node.
What is the requirement for disk space ?
no special requirement. as long as the system can run k8s/docker.
See comment above
What is the breakdown between infrastructure and application ?
let's me elaborate it more
yes
2G is minimum request running Stx worker node(system services such as container , k8s kuberlet etc). the memory request is really depends on app.
Agree with Brent, if 2G is total memory in computes, we need to figure out the minimum memory for the reserved platform. Or it is just minimum memory for reserved that StarlingX can supports.
do you mean how many memory will be run for system ? and how many memory will be run as application?

Are you saying only one interface ? 
What would the applications use for I/O ?
Network/network
How many interfaces would this node support ?

> If so, that means the only nic is not used for StarlingX mgmt
 > network only, it should contain mgmt and service networks both.

Yes. mgmt networks is used for mgmt and service as normal worker node.
If so, that means the only nic is not used for StarlingX mgmt network only, it should contain mgmt and service networks both.
In theory , 1 interface is enough, same as normal compute node w/o openstack.
sorry, I did not get this question.
If openstack applications are not scheduled to run on this kind of nodes and this kind of nod is not good for master, then what kind of applications are going to be executed on this?
This depends on application requirement.
Sorry if I did nto explain my self clear: What kind of orchestraitor is going to be set for the low memory node? k8 or open stack ?
Perfect, it was not clear to me , + 1
k8s. as mentioned , small node was joined into k8s cluster.
mgmt network
will fix

Which flock services ?

the flock services which are running on worker node.
such as hbsClient, sysinv-agent,mtcClient, lmond,fsmond,etc.

The containerized flock services themselves are not managed to reduce memory footprint.
the memory reduction comes from 
1) no reserved memory limitation 
2) The different os installed reduces system memory.
as talked, the OS will be pre-installed into such small node. any OS which can be as k8s node should be ok.

The services and the OS consume the memory. Which management are you referring to that consumes the memory

Which OS's ?
Why do you want to bypass pxe installation?
So how would you install it ?
The DevOps install it by themselves.
How ?
answer 2 questions together, the node's os/system is installed before adding the StarlingX.
Why use ansible vs what is already available ?
ansible is agentless services.  we suppose the small node was pre-installed standard OS w/o any flock services yet.  need ansible to bring-up flock services.
There is no lvm on a worker node w/o openstack
if I remember , /dev/cgts-vg/docker-lv etc are using lvm
yeah, some system is use physical volume to manager volume docker using.
You will need docker if you want to run containers.
Please take a look at how kube edge is solving htis issue. They create a 2 mb binary to communicate w/ a kubernetes node
I was not saying that we implement kubeedge as it is to STX, I am saying that we explore how they are doing the addition of compute node to the k8 infrastructure, to take some ideas from there.
Thanks. Yeah, I'm checking kubeedge and rancher/k3s to learn more.

"the approach for StarlingX to support small footprint compute nodes."

In the current StarlingX system, the OS on compute nodes is CentOS while the hardware requirements include more than 8G of memory and VT.  This spec proposes to add "small compute nodes" to StarlingX but with limited functionality compared to normal compute nodes. This will allow StarlingX to manage workloads on small Edge devices that are important to Industrial and Telco use cases.

if need run openstack application, then cpu need support VT, if other general purpose application, So no special request for CPU.

If we allow any OS to join a cluster, how many do we test and/or validate? What happens if the OS has a problem that prevents the services from running? the approach should be something like starlingx application, stx just provides the mechanism store the os, install the os upgrade/downgrade os on worker node, if all flock services are containerized and then can be deploy on that worker node. 
then customer maintain and is response for that os image.

nitty nit: please fix alignment with line above

Make sense, I removed the version field in the new patch.
I guess that "remote_ip_prefix", "remote_group_id" and "remote_address_group_id" are exclusive.
Yes, it is mentioned in L539. Also added to the description here in the new patch.

specs/victoria/address-groups-support-in.message: should we mixed IPv4 and IPv6 in one group? Maybe better would be to have groups only with one type of addresses?
I prefer to let one address group can hold both v4 and v6 addresses, which is similar to a port and easy to use. The logic to distinguish v4 and v6 addresses can easily be done on the server-side.
so, how it will work if ethertype is IPv4 and You will have IPv6 addresses in the address group?

The behavior should be similar to using a remote-security-group in the rule. When the remote security group is bond with ports with both v4 and v6 addresses, the rule will only be applied to the addresses matching with the rule's ethertype. The logic will be handled on server-side.
it's not for this spec and RFE but IMO it would be good to add RBAC support for that in the future.
Yes, that's in my plan as well. I added RBAC to the work items list.

instead? I'm worried about getting garbage back and interpreting this as a special condition. Assuming only the 'version' field is missing, this will establish that things look some bit sane, anyway.

Making this configurable sounds reasonable, yes.

bsp-files/kickstarts/pre_disk_setup_comm.message:
In an upgrade, we are only wiping the rootfs/boot disk. The reason we're explicitly wiping everything for cgts-vg was because it could have volumes on secondary disks as well, but was definitely on the root disk. If we didn't wipe it from the other disks, we'd have an issue.

This code will wipe ALL volumes from ALL disks, however, without consideration of an upgrade. I think you need to check here, if you're in an upgrade, that you're only wiping volume groups with volumes on the root/boot disk.

Are you sure the VG that caused a problem was a VG other than cgts-vg?
Looking at the config for this particular lab, it looks like a case where nova-local happens to be created on the root disk.

Yeah, we should wipe only VGs that have PVs on root/boot disk, regardless of upgrade state. The other disks don't cause issues.

Re upgrades, how do we know, from kickstarts, we are doing an AIO-SX upgrade?
For the other installs is easy (we already do it at line 57) yet for AIO-SX we don't have the controller to ask him. We can store a flag file inside the Platform Upgrade persistent partition but, to my knowledge, is not implemented.

nit: nova-local

Better to explain that you're removing VGs for any with PVs on the root disk, as opposed to listing expected ones
Will this result in us no longer removing the vg if there are no pvs in the vg? Looks like the old code would have removed the lv in that case.

I don't think we'd need to worry about cgts-vg being empty. Not sure what it would mean for another VG... where would the metadata be held? If it's on the root disk, it would presumably get wiped with the disk. I think our issue is primarily with the PVs, not the VGs

What is the role of bootfs? Never used it but IMHO it's only used to install grub on it (e.g. system boots from sda and we put grub on it but all the other partitions are on another disk that, for whatever reason, can't be selected as boot disk from bios). 

If above assumption is correct all stx partitions are created on rootfs and the wipe is also for rootfs => it's safe to grep only rootfs here.

The hard question: Do we test with separate bootfs and rootfs? :)

After reinstall LVM is empty but it scans all disks in the system for PVs and recreates the VGs (haven't tested it, but that's what I know about lvm). So, all vgs that are found after reinstall should have PVs in them.

Only thing I'd note here is the potential for boot_device and rootfs_device to be different disks, which would be rare. So you may want:
pvs --select "vg_name=$vg" --noheadings -o pv_name | grep -q -e "$(get_disk $rootfs_device)" -e "$(get_disk $boot_device)"

It's tricky. Let's say you use a flavor like so:

  openstack flavor create \
    --vcpus 4 --disk 5 --ram 2048 \
    --property 'hw:cpu_policy=dedicated' \

Today, you'll see the following failure:

That's because we don't have an emulator thread policy configured and all of cores are set aside for realtime, meaning we end up with an empty emulator thread set [1]. However, we can do what you suggest by configuring an emulator thread policy. For example:

  openstack flavor create \
    --vcpus 4 --disk 5 --ram 2048 \
    --property 'hw:cpu_policy=dedicated' \
    --property 'hw:emulator_threads_policy=share' \
    --property 'hw:cpu_realtime=true' \
    --property 'hw:cpu_realtime_mask=0-3' \

This took me aaaaages to figure out too :D I was hoping this was easier to understand, but clearly it isn't. What we're aiming to get is a list of all unique sets of siblings (note: list is important since it has to be sorted, and set is important since we don't want duplicates). It's probably easiest to visualize with some code. Here's an example using the XML from my own laptop:

  >>> from nova.virt.libvirt import config
  >>> xml = """
  ... <cell id='0'>
  ...   <memory unit='KiB'>19885704</memory>
  ...   <pages unit='KiB' size='4'>4971426</pages>
  ...   <pages unit='KiB' size='2048'>0</pages>
  ...   <pages unit='KiB' size='1048576'>0</pages>
  ...   <distances>
  ...     <sibling id='0' value='10'/>
  ...   </distances>
  ...   <cpus num='4'>
  ...     <cpu id='0' socket_id='0' core_id='0' siblings='0,2'/>
  ...     <cpu id='1' socket_id='0' core_id='1' siblings='1,3'/>
  ...     <cpu id='2' socket_id='0' core_id='0' siblings='0,2'/>
  ...     <cpu id='3' socket_id='0' core_id='1' siblings='1,3'/>
  ...   </cpus>
  ... </cell>
  ... """
  >>> cell = config.LibvirtConfigCapsNUMACell()
  >>> cell.parse_str(xml)
  >>> sorted(set(x) for x in set(tuple(cpu.siblings) or () for cpu in cell.cpus))
  [{1, 3}, {0, 2}]

We have to use tuple(cpu.siblings) and not set since sets aren't immutable and therefore aren't hashable.

  >>> sorted(set(x) for x in set(set(cpu.siblings) or () for cpu in cell.cpus))
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  TypeError: unhashable type: 'set'

Perhaps it would be better if I unrolled this list comprehension and just use bog-standard for loops?

Thanks got it now (and learned a new word bog-standard).

So cpu.siblings is a set but we want to deduplicate sibling sets by putting them in a set, but that needs a hashable type, like tuple. But at the end we want to covert back the sibling tuples to sibling sets. Maybe it worth a code comment describing the intention of this code. :)

Question/suggestion: visually, I'd much prefer if we didn't have the 'ty.' prefix everywhere, so I'd feel

  from typing import List, Set, Dict

would be cleaner. And then we could just say, for example:

  def parse_cpu_spec(spec: str) -> Set[int]

However, maybe that goes against convention/best practices?

Yup, that's what we have in hardware.py [1] at the moment. It's certainly possible but I'd still personally much rather keep this stuff namespaced. I've written a good amount of this stuff [2][3] and doing it this way does tend to lead to clearer type signatures. It's also what we do for everything else that isn't translations.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/5c119a21ea/nova/virt/hardware.py#L20
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/q/status:open+project:openstack/nova+branch:master+topic:mypy-integration
[3] https://review.opendev.org/#/q/status:open+project:openstack/nova+branch:master+topic:pytype
We wouldn't have to `from typing import *` - just the specific types we need. Doing a quick search, I can't find any examples of Dict, or List, or Set that's not in docstrings.

I initially went that way, but decided not to because you'd be surprised how often the various types this expose conflict with existing classes and attributes we have here. 'ty.' seemed like the least intrusive approach to namespacing I could do
